examples.text: six of Sweden’s top financial experts
Ten people were invited but only six turned up.
Can you lend me six dollars?
I can't read your writing—is this meant to be a six?
The bulbs are planted in fours or sixes *(= groups of four or six)*.
We moved to America when I was six *(= six years old)*.
Shall we meet at six *(= at six o'clock)*, then?

definitions.definition: a hit that scores six runs (= points)
in a confused state; not well organized

examples.text: I haven't had time to clear up, so I'm all at sixes and sevens.

definitions.definition: to be dead and buried in the ground

examples.text: The business over the lawsuit had really knocked her for six.

definitions.definition: used to say that there is not much real difference between two possible choices

wordOrigin: Old English siex, six, syx, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zes and German sechs, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin sex and Greek hex.
